title: 4 EU countries agree on migration relocation system
text:
Germany's Interior Minister Horst Seehofer arrives to attend a meeting of Interior ministers from four EU countries, France, Germany, Italy and Malta on September 23, 2019 in Valletta, Malta | Matthew Mirabelli/AFP via Getty Images 4 EU countries agree on migration relocation system Scheme will be temporary and voluntary.

BIRGU, Malta — Four EU countries on Monday agreed on a temporary scheme to relocate asylum seekers rescued in the Central Mediterranean — but it's likely to run into opposition elsewhere in the bloc.

The interior ministers of Germany, France, Italy and Malta produced a plan that will be presented to their counterparts in the 24 other EU countries at a meeting at the start of October, said Maltese Interior Minister Michael Farrugia.

“It's a process that wasn't easy,” he added.

Ministers even skipped lunch, opting for sandwiches while they worked, and postponed the traditional family photo at the end of the meeting, an EU official said. “I'm sorry but failing today wasn't an option,” said one of the diplomats who took part in the preparatory work.

Discussion on migration has been stuck as EU countries struggled to find consensus on how to reform an asylum policy whose failure to cope with an influx of migrants in the wake of the 2015 crisis led five member states to reimpose internal border controls.

The text of the agreement has not been made public but German Interior Minister Horst Seehofer said he was “moderately optimistic” that “chances have increased” of reaching a deal on reform of EU asylum policy.

Other participants stressed it was a first step and Migration Commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos called on “all member states to join us in our work to establish a more predictable solidarity mechanism” for asylum seekers rescued at sea.

Discussions started after Matteo Salvini, Italy's now former interior minister, closed ports to NGO vessels that rescued migrants in the Central Mediterranean. Rescue vessels found themselves stranded at sea, hoping that a country would open its gates and other countries would then take in the rescued asylum seekers.

“I find crucial that we move away from a ship-to-ship arrangement,” said Maria Ohisalo, the interior minister of Finland, which holds the rotating presidency of the Council of the EU.

The paper that will be presented to other member states “is a pilot case, limited in time and focused on disembarkations after search and rescue operations ... ensuring swift relocation of asylum seekers on a voluntary basis to other member states,” she said.

But the agreement reached in Malta contains some words — such as “quotas” and “mandatory” — that have caused problems in the past. It may also prove controversial because it refers repeatedly to asylum seekers and migrants, rather than to refugees, which could open the scheme up to people less likely to be granted international protection for reasons such as persecution or war.

“There are concrete proposals and I'm very satisfied,” new Italian Interior Minister Luciana Lamorgese told reporters. Germany has publicly announced that it is ready to take in a quarter of the asylum seekers rescued, but Lamorgese said quotas will be set only once it is clear how many countries will take part in the relocation scheme.

One of the points agreed upon in Malta is the controversial “voluntary rotation of ports” where asylum seekers will disembark, she said.

Another key aspect is that participation will be voluntary but, once quotas are agreed, “relocation will be mandatory,” the Italian minister said. Diplomats from other countries confirmed this aspect of the scheme. It was a mandatory aspect of a previous relocation scheme for refugees, launched in 2015 at the peak of the migration crisis, that infuriated Central European countries such as Hungary and Poland.

The other step that could upset countries opposed to mandatory relocation is that “we talk about asylum seekers [not refugees] and you have to take into account that 99 percent [of those arriving] are asylum seekers,” Lamorgese said.
description: Scheme will be temporary and voluntary.
